experiment_name: Vehicle Collision Prediction - Binary Classification with Exposure-Based Features
key_findings: Exposure-based feature engineering significantly improved model performance (+13% relative improvement over baseline)
RandomForestClassifier with balanced class weights proved optimal for this imbalanced classification task
Model shows strong discrimination ability (ROC-AUC = 0.805) but struggles with precision due to severe class imbalance
Top features are dominated by driving exposure metrics, validating the core hypothesis
Model exhibits poor probability calibration, particularly over-estimating risk at medium confidence levels
strengths: Strong discrimination ability with ROC-AUC of 0.805
Reasonable recall (35.16%) for highly imbalanced dataset
Comprehensive evaluation framework with multiple visualizations
Successful MLflow model packaging for production deployment
weaknesses: PR-AUC (0.238) falls short of minimum target (0.25)
Low precision (22.38%) leading to high false positive rate
Poor probability calibration across confidence levels
Limited feature set missing contextual information (weather, traffic, demographics)
Model performance heavily constrained by severe class imbalance

issues: Over-calibrated at medium confidence levels (14-35% predicted vs 7-8% actual)
Under-calibrated at high confidence levels (82% predicted vs 60% actual)

immediate_improvements: Implement threshold optimization based on business costs
Apply probability calibration techniques (Platt scaling or isotonic regression)
Explore ensemble methods combining RandomForest with other algorithms
Engineer temporal features and interaction terms
strategic_enhancements: Collect additional contextual features (weather, traffic density, demographics)
Implement cost-sensitive learning with asymmetric loss functions
Develop temporal modeling to capture seasonal and time-of-day patterns
Integrate external data sources for road and traffic conditions

next_iteration_focus: Advanced feature engineering with temporal patterns
